There may be some mileage in using multi-objective evolution where 
instead of using parameters, the things they change are factored in as 
extra dimensions to optimise on.

Stephen Waits wrote:
>
>
> On Nov 7, 2007, at 6:44 AM, Jeff Clune wrote:
>
> > Beware: evolution is very bad at choosing good settings for evolution.
> > That's in addition to all of the extra computation time.
>
> This is a rather broad statement, and, paper or not, I don't buy it.
> I believe a Differential Evolution would work *very* well to choose
> NEAT parameters.
>
> I've thought of doing this very thing myself. Like the OP, I find the
> hand-tuning of the numerous NEAT parameters inelegant and painful.
> --
> Stephen Waits
> steve@... <mailto:steve%40waits.net>
> http://swaits.com/ <http://swaits.com/>
>
>
